Dependency : https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/67051
Dependency : https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/67051
It seems the latest libpldm will cause the header "#include <libpldm/pldm.h>" not found.
This still needs to be fixed, even if you're the one to discover it...
The current libpldm fixed.

Do not use static globals.  Put this into the OEM handler.

"slop"? 😄
Done
Please remove these excess spaces (same comment on all of your lg2 calls).
Ack
You don't need `.what()` on any lg2 calls.  lg2 handles that for you.
Ack
I'd prefer a static constexpr for the string constant so that you don't have to use `[0]` everywhere.  Everytime I see that I have to think "why is it the zero-th entry?"
Ack

Can we change the EM config to put the slot identifier at the end?

I'd really prefer we are not trying to parse any dbus object_path like this.  Ideally we'd have a proper position identifier put into the dbus interface created by EM.

There is Inventory/Decorator/Slot and Inventory/Decorator/LocationCode.  LocationCode isn't intended to be parsed by computers, but it is at least better (I'd expect the LocationCode on the Sentinel Dome to be something like "slotN").  Ideally the baseboard would create a Slot for the Sentinel Dome to be populated in.
Done. Base on https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/66750 design
Shouldn't we do something to ensure the part we picked out is actually an integer?
Done
constexpr
auto?
Use auto dbusObjStr will be empty.
Use constexpr dbusObjStr cannot connect with char.
I am surprised this type isn't in a header file somewhere.
Ack
How do you know this is 4 (or less) bytes?
AMD platform send four bytes as a post code unit
This assumes little endian order?  Why is that?
The postcode sent from bic is Little-Endian and here turns to Big-Endian

You shouldn't use quote-include for a header you're planning to install.  These paths will be wrong after the install.

Also, it seems like you're adding headers into a header file without using all of the content.  It isn't obvious, for example, why `requester/handler.hpp` is here.  Make sure you only include-what-you-use.

I might have misunderstood that this is currently in pldmd and not libpldm.  Might be no issue on the quote-include.

Still should look at IWYU.
Done
This implies we could never multi-thread and/or async the handling of PLDM messages, which doesn't seem like a good direction.  Shouldn't we add this to the request pldm_msg structure?
After reading DSP0240, the tid doesn't exist in PLDM message header fields. We are thinking about adding tid as a parameter in each handler. Or any suggestion for it ?

Please ask other PLDM maintainers to weigh in here.

I'm not sure why it not being in the message header matters, unless that struct is intended to be the raw message header (but then why is it passed around as if it is an API?)
Done. The factor code has been merged.
Done
nit: Meta isn't an acronym.
Done

I'm a little concern that this file is going to become unwieldy since you're trying to do a number of independent things in a single PLDM command.  I'd suggest one file for the general "I have a file_io" command and separate files for each distinct piece of functionality.
Ongoing moving to another file.
Done

I'm not convinced this return is useful.

- This isn't a real PLDM message response, so why are we using `PLDM_SUCCESS`, etc?
- It seems nobody does anything with the return, so what is the point?
- If we are going to have a return, why isn't it of type `pldm_completion_codes` (if that's really what we want to do)?
Remove. Change to way using from https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/pldm/+/51184

Why are we still doing a split of the object_path if we switched to using EM config to get the slot identifier?  The previous comment I made about this was marked done, but I still see the string splitting.

Is this not actually a "slotNum"?  What is this used for?
Currently we can only get bic location via object path. Or we need to add a location property in EM so that we can get bic location directly?
We added Decorator.Slot at Yosemite4's board layer to get the slot number, a new change will be pushed to EntityManager.
char??  Maybe this should be an integer and use `to_string`?  Please don't pass a real ASCII character around as a string-portion like this.
Modified to using integer.
Should we make this a switch?
Where does POST_CODE come from?  Is this something you put into libpldm (if so, why)?  Why isn't it a C++ `enum class`?
move from libpldm to pldm
Done
We probably should move the parsing of the message contents to the postCodeHandler function (based on my suggestion that we move all the post code handling out into a separate file anyhow).
Ongoing moving to another file.
Done
We should probably return in either case.
Done
Aren't we returning a successful response in this case, but we actually had an error?  For example if the `fileIOType != POST_CODE` we end up here.
Modified to return PLDM_ERROR_UNSUPPORTED_PLDM_CMD
Is there anything we can do about it?  Just hope someone sees the message in the journal?
Remove. Change to way using from https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/pldm/+/51184
Should this be private?
Done
Modified enum item name base on libpldm suggestion
Proposed https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc-build-scripts/+/67923 as a fix for the CI issue.

This is expected behavior. You're trying to use an API before it is exposed by the library. The way to get this to pass is to submit a patch marking the API as stable.

I wrote about how to do it here if you want to deal with the ABI dumps yourself:

https://amboar.github.io/notes/2023/06/26/managing-the-libpldm-abi-reference-dumps.html

Things have changed a little bit (no more aarch64 dump, current.dump is now in build/src/current.dump, just use the docker image to generate the dump).

I'm also happy to deal with the ABI dumps myself if you submit a patch changing the annotation from `LIBPLDM_ABI_TESTING` to LIBPLDM_ABI_STABLE`. I'll push it back with the dump update included

Here's an example stabilisation commit for reference:

https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/commit/4a307bca7a6a06b76b6c628807dcbe3965ebdccd
Compile failure needs to be resolved.
Acknowledged

This looks reasonable to me. I've pushed a stabilisation patch for the API in libpldm:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/67952
Acknowledged
Rebase to the latest commit.
can you expand what is BIC ?
Changed to using `multiple hosts` be more specific.
typo
Remove redundant commit message
There are a lot of unresolved comments that weren't responded to or marked resolved.  Please resolve all outstanding comments.
Ack

you could actually do this in one single line

```
add_project_arguments('-DOEM_META', language : ['c','cpp'])
```

we could change the ibm one's in a later commit
Done
we could have this enabled by default, so that repo CI could make sure we dont break this while adding code.
Done

move this to line number 166

where Vendor Specific Options are defined.
Done

Do we need to do anything to skip running this function if we've already ran it?

How do we handle hot-plug of a compute card since it appears we only run this when `Handler` is constructed.
Remove. Change to way using from https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/pldm/+/51184
auto handler = getHandlerByType(tid, fileIOType);
Done

Prefer to use the boolean operator rather than comparison with nullptr.

`if (!handler)`
Done

Suggest to use span instead of vector to avoid data copies.

```
auto data = std::span(std::begin(retDataField), length);
```
Done
Use modern nested namespaces: `namespace pldm::responder::oem_meta`
Done
Should this and setupTidToSlotMappingTable be moved as static members of Handler?
Remove. Change to way using from https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/pldm/+/51184
Do we need a longer name or namespace here to differentaite this as the "file_io handler"?
Done
pldm_tid_t?
Done
pldm_tid_t?
Done
Suggest switching both of these vectors to a span.  Add a `using` alias somewhere for them.  Maybe in `Handler`.
Done
Need to catch this potential exception?
Done
Do we need a catch that ensures `distance(std::begin(postCodeList), std::end(postCodeList)) <= sizeof(primaryPostCode)`?
Done
prefer auto
Done
What is the purpose in the reply?  Is there anything we need to do with this?
Remove
tid_t?
Done
Just drop `data` instead of the `maybe_unused` (reduce the noise).
Done
Should this be a reference or a new copy?
Make a `using` alias for this type.
Remove. Change to way using from https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/pldm/+/51184
Remove. Change to way using from https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/pldm/+/51184
Ongoing fix ci compile failure.
Rename all files in the oem/meta directory to start with oem_meta to avoid file name conflicts.

I'm not enamoured with encoding the directory hierarchy in the base file name of the libpldmresponder sources. I'm also not enamoured with the top-level `oem/` directory that encourages that either. It would be nice to see that all refactored so that each top level directory has an `oem/` subdirectory (using the philosophy of keeping-things-that-are-together-together), but I'm not going to _require_ you to do it.
This commit also dependent on: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/68449
What if that commit isn't included?  Hopefully this code does something reasonable?
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/68449 is for knowing the TID belongs to which slot so that we can store its postcode history.

You didn't answer what the code does if that EM commit isn't there.  If the code crashes the PLDM daemon due to a missing or corrupted EEPROM, we need to fix that.  I don't expect correct functionality, but I expect reasonable behavior.
It wouldn't cause pldmd crash but only pop up lots of error messages for property not found when the host power is on.

@Andrew - Are you suggesting these should be just 'file_io'?  I agree these file names are a bit long.

I guess you're saying that these should be in `libpldmresponder/oem/meta` instead?  That part we should probably handle as a move of everything in `oem/` at once.
yes and agree
pldm_tid_t?
spelling: discovery
nit: suggest initialization (` = 0;`)

spelling: discovery.

(fix throughout)
Why is this a pointer and not a reference?

Is this const?  I suspect we need to write to it?  Or does it need to return data instead of int?  We don't really have an example of read from what I can tell yet, so I'm not sure how we define a good API for it.
Why?  You converted a C++ string into a C string only to have it converted into a _new_ C++ string as part of calling this function.

You caught an exception and then just logged a message and continue?  In what conditions is someone ever going to see this log message?

We've now left slotNum uninitialized due to how this API is written and the calling code.

Should we just be crashing here (leave the exception uncaught and/or re-throw it)?
Not necessary.
slotNum is uninitialized.
Use a type here and not a number.  `ObjectPath`?
Why?  This is kind of strange that the utils.hpp code is using C-strings.  Can we fix all of that?
Use a type and not a number.
Interesting... we have a final throw here but there are many paths through this code where we just log a message and return empty-handed.  Please make this consistent.
Why use this?  `>` isn't good enough?
`postCodeList.size()` ?  Make sure you also change the comparison to `>=` if needed, but I think `>` is right.
Isn't this parameter suppose to be an interface and not a service?
Suggest a using-alias for this type.
Should we just return the slot #?  I don't see the value of passing it as an input-reference.
size_t?  I understand that the MCTP configuration might be using a uint64_t, but it seems safe to use a size_t internally here so we don't let that part of the API leak into the rest of the code.
